text: America is a black country. Let me
explain why. As a Marxist, the way that
I understand how nations develop their
national trajectories is through the
class struggle. So the struggle that
different forces in society with
contradictory interest wage in order to
try to advance their own specific
interests. In the US, as the polymath
web dubo argued, the central form that
the class struggle took was the struggle
against the color line. the struggle
against racism. It was the struggle that
propelled the second American
Revolution, the Civil War, where uh
quite literally you had slaves free
themselves, what he called the black
proletariat free itself through a
general strike. This is not how we're
taught the Civil War. But objectively,
what happened in the Civil War was that
southern slaves, black workers,
fled to the north. And by fleeing to the
north, they removed the productive base
of the US South and added spies,
workers, and very capable soldiers to
the US North and won the war.
Try to think of a more influential event
for American history than the Civil War.
That was a class struggle. It was a its
victory was a product of the class
struggle of the black proletariat. Then
you have the political revolution, the
civil rights movement of the 1960s which
radically changes society. It dour,
eliminates, legalized aparthide
segregation. Again, this struggle was a
product of the black freedom movement of
the class struggle against the color
line. And this isn't just a race
struggle. Markx used to say that racism
is the secret through which the ruling
class sustains its power. So if you're
fighting against that secret through
which the ruling class sustains its
power, it's pretty foolish just to call
it a race struggle. No, it's the class
struggle taking on a specific form as
the black freedom movement. So if
America is a country that has had the
most important and central class
struggles in its history taken the form
of that black freedom movement of that
movement against slavery and then
against Jim Crow aparthide
all of the things that have been
produced as a reflection of that in
terms of culture in terms of art, music,
uh literature uh philosophy sociology
you know some of the main influences for
what we call American culture, they come
from that black freedom movement. So in
a certain sense, if we consider, as I do
in my tradition, which can be traced
back to Hegel, that subjectivity, who it
is that you are, your identity is
basically constituted through struggle.
In the master slave dialectic, in the
ultimate instance, it's the slave, the
bondsman that's capable of constituting
themselves as a fully human subject
precisely because of their work. they
can recognize themselves in that
struggle in their product. It is
precisely because of that that the only
genuine form of social subjectivity that
could in any form define America as a
nation is the one that has been born out
of that black freedom movement. So in
that sense, America is definitely and
here's it's a very controversial point.
I understand that it is because of the
history of white supremacy and uh Jim
Crow and everything else, but precisely
because of that and how that has defined
class struggles in our country, America
is a black nation. America is a nation
that has been constituted culturally and
in terms of its identity through the
black freedom movement, which has been
the dominant form that the class
struggle has taken at least up until
1964 with the civil rights political
revolution.
